text:
Fourth Avenue north from 32nd Street, showing Park Avenue Hotel. 1880.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Fourth Avenue, north on west side from 32nd to 34th Streets. The Park Avenue Hotel, originally built in the 1870's by A.T. Stewart is a semi-charitable organization, on the site of the old N.Y. & Harlem Railway round-house (engine-house). It will stand here till 1925, (see Park Avenue). Compare this with the same view in 1906 (by Brown Bros.), which will show little change beyond better pavement, electrified street-cars, and subway entrances at 33rd Street. The old frame hotel and bar on the S.W. corner of 32nd Street will not be demolished till after 1910. About 1895.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

East side of Fourth Avenue north from 32nd Street, showing 71st Regiment Armory at left.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographer.
Neg #76?

Park Avenue Hotel, west side of Fourth Avenue, north from 32nd Street.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

Park Avenue, north from 32nd Street and Fourth Avenue, a point just north of the old Sunfish Pond.
The Street car tunnel is the old tunnel under Murray Hill cut by the New York and Harlem Railway in its early days. An engine house with a turntable stood where the Armory is now located, and there was a roundhouse or engine house in the block where the Park Avenue Hotel is shown. The name Park Avenue was first applied to that portion of Fourth Avenue between 34th and 42nd Streets, and is so shown on maps, with the little green parks in the middle of the avenue in each block, as early as 1867. Above 42nd Street the name Park Avenue was not applied till nearly 1890. After the building of the first Grand Central Station in 1870, train service down to Madison Square was discontinued, and the tunnel taken over by the horse-cars. In 1898 this surface line was electrified. In 1935, when the Madison and Fourth Avenue street cars have been superseded by buses, the tunnel will be remodeled for automobile traffic.
On the east side from 32nd to 33rd Streets stand the barbarns of the Metropolitan Street Railway; they will be torn down in 1925. The 71st Regiment Armory, shown in the next block, was erected in 1893. On the west side of the avenue, the Park Avenue Hotel, built by A. T. Stewart in the 1870's, will give place in 1926 to the new No. 2 Park Avenue building. On either side of 33rd Street may be seen subway entrances; the subway has been open about two years. The 333rd to 34th Street block, west, will be demolished in 1910 to make room for the Vanderbilt Hotel.
On the horizon may be seen the new Hotel Belmont on the southwest corner of 42nd Street, and one dome of the old Grand Central Station. Compare this picture with Galloway's view of the west side of the avenue, looking north from this point, in 1930.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.

Fourth Avenue, west side, from 32nd to 34th Streets, showing the old Park Avenue Hotel and the new Vanderbilt Hotel nearing completion. The view is from the roof of the old Fourth Avenue Railway (Metropolitan Railway) carbarns. At the N.W. corner of 34th Street, the first building on that side of Park Avenue, stands the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, later known as the Community Church, erected in 1867. To the right, on the east side of the Avenue opposite the Vanderbilt Hotel, stands the 71st Regiment Armory (1893).

1911.

Park Ave., east side, north from but not including 32nd Street, to and including 33rd Street.
January, 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Park Avenue between 32nd and 33rd Streets, looking west from the excavation on the east of the avenue. In the foreground the old street railway carbarns have been demolished, and the ground is being prepared for the 18-story office building to be called No. 1 Park Avenue. On the N. E. corner of 33rd Street stands the 71st Regiment Armory. On the west side between 32nd and 33rd Streets, the old Park Avenue Hotel is shortly to be demolished and replaced by another office building. Opposite the Armory stands the Vanderbilt Hotel (erected 1911).

1925.

Drix Duryea, Photographer.
 with credit.

Park Avenue, east side, north from 32nd Street, showing the new One Park Avenue building, just completed, the 71st Regiment Armory, and the new Fred F. French apartment houses on the S. E. corner of 35th Street.

April 1926.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.

Park Avenue, east side, from E. 32nd (right) to 33rd (left) Streets, showing the New York and Harlem Railroad carbarns. The photographer is viewing same in a south eastward direction from a vantage point at the N. W. corner of Park Avenue and E. 33rd Street
(Vanderbilt Hotel today).
At the time this photo was taken, this thoroughfare was Fourth Avenue; Park Avenue beginning at 34th Street. When the present multi-story building No. 1 Park Avenue was erected, this Avenue was extended southward to begin at 32nd Street. In the renumbering, this office building took the number formerly held by Mrs. Bacon at the N. E. corner of Park Avenue and E. 34th Street.

Behind the board fence in the foreground ran the trains to Harlem, thru the tunnel to Grand Central Station at 42nd Street. It was here that the famous Tunnel Gang originated and from which came Boss Crocker of Tammany, a worthy successor to Boss Tweed.

In earlier days this was the bed of Sunfish Pond. The ground slope clearly seen here indicates the size and depth of same.

Remaining today (1939) are only two of the buildings appearing here. They are the 4 story structure seen at the left margin and the St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church at the right. No. 197 Lexington Avenue, the first mentioned, is now an automobile garage.

1860's

Park Avenue, west side, north from and including 32nd Street. The new Park Avenue Building, on the west side from 32nd to 33rd Streets, was built in 1927, on the site of the old Park Avenue Hotel. The Vanderbilt Hotel, in the next block north, was built in 1911. Two street cars of the Madison and Fourth Avenue line are shown, a downtown car waiting for the light at 32nd Street, and an uptown car about to plunge into the old railway tunnel, which will be made over for automobile traffic in 1935, after this street car line has been discontinued and superseded by motor coaches.

The Community Church (Unitarian), on the N.W. corner of 34th Street, will be demolished in 1931; and its place will be taken by an apartment building. The new Union League clubhouse will be built in 1930 on the S.W. corner of 37th Street. Up at 41st to 42nd Streets the Hotel Belmont, rising from behind the old Murray Hill Hotel, will be demolished in 1931. At the time of this picture the old Lincoln Bank building, adjoining the Biltmore at 42nd Street, has not yet been demolished; and the tower of the New York Central Building, north of the Grand Central Station, is still under construction.

September 28, 1928.

New York Edison Company Collection.

Park Avenue, east side, north from 32nd Street, showing the Seventy-First Regiment Armory (1893) from 33rd to 34th Streets, with a little of the new Number One Park Avenue building visible on the S.E. corner of 33rd Street.
In the background the New York Central Building at 46th Street rises over the Grand Central Station.
March 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

Park Avenue, east side, north from 32nd Street, showing the New York Central building over the roof of the Grand Central Station. The two blocks from 32nd to 34th Streets began to be called Park Avenue upon completion of the new buildings No. 1 and No. 2 Park Avenue, between 32nd and 33rd Street, in 1926-27. No. 2 is shown here in the left foreground, on the site of the old Park Avenue Hotel. The block from 33rd to 34th Street is occupied by the Vanderbilt Hotel (1911). At the N. W. corner of 34th Street is the Community Church (Unitarian), shortly to be demolished. On the S. W. corner of 37th Street the Union League Club's new house is nearing completion. To the left of the Grand Central Station stands the Hotel Belmont, on the west side, from 41st Street to 42nd Street. Built about 1904, it is shortly to be demolished. To the left of it rises the tall Lincoln Building, 60 East 42nd Street, and directly in front of it may be seen the old Murray Hill Hotel, between 40th and 41st Streets. Compare this with Brown Brothers' photograph of Park Avenue north from 32nd Street in 1906. 1930. Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Looking south on Fourth Avenue from 1Park Avenue at 32nd Street; east side. Skyline of lower Manhattan may be seen faintly in the background.

February 27, 1931.

P.L. Sperr, photographer.
